persona.name: Claudia Murillo Aguilar

occupation.title: Informal retail vendor / small shop owner (commerce & retail)
occupation.organization: Self-employed — market stall and occasional door-to-door sales; sells ready-to-eat regional snacks and some low-cost clothing/accessories
occupation.description: Claudia runs a small informal business in a busy neighborhood market near Puebla's municipal transit hub. She operates early mornings and afternoons, selling an assortment of items: tamales and atole on market days, packaged snacks, affordable blouses, scarves and costume jewelry, and seasonal items (school supplies, holiday decorations). Her work is entirely informal (no registered business, no employee benefits). She sources goods from small wholesalers in the city and occasionally buys on consignment from a cousin who brings items from Mexico City. Responsibilities include: preparing food on-site (when she sells snacks), procuring inventory weekly, negotiating prices with wholesalers, setting up and cleaning the stall, tallying daily cash, handling customer relations, and helping family with household tasks. She sometimes hires a younger cousin to help on Saturdays and during festivals. Her skills include negotiation, quick mental math for cash transactions, basic food preparation, and reading customer preferences. Income is variable: some weeks she earns enough to cover bills and put aside a small amount; other weeks she struggles to cover both business costs and household expenses. She occasionally uses informal credit from a local tienda or buys on credit from wholesalers.

persona.residence: Puebla, Puebla, Mexico (urban, mid-sized city in the Central region)
persona.education: Completed secundaria and preparatoria (equivalent to finishing high school). Attended a short municipal evening course on microbusiness management and basic bookkeeping (certificate). Did not pursue higher education due to need to work and help support the family from age 17.
long_term_goals: Save enough to repair and expand her small shop/stall into a more permanent local storefront with a nearby storage room.
Give both children the chance to finish university or a professional technical degree so they won’t have to struggle as she did.
Own a small freezer and a second moped/motorbike to make deliveries and increase sales.
Have a modest retirement cushion so she is not dependent on anyone in old age.
Be recognized in her neighborhood as a reliable, helpful person (someone people trust and ask advice from).
Keep the family close — preserve traditions and frequent multi-generational gatherings.
persona.style: Warm, direct, and practical. Speaks central Mexican Spanish with Puebla-district colloquialisms and a slight tendency to use diminutives when addressing children and customers ("mi amorcito", "un momentito"). Polite and chatty with regular clients; when stressed she speaks more abruptly but tries to soften it with humor. Body language is expressive — she gestures with her hands while telling stories, tilts her head when listening, and leans forward to make a sale. In the market she dresses in bright, practical clothes: a clean apron over a cotton blouse, comfortable sandals, and always a small cross necklace. When meeting church friends or extended family she adds a shawl and light makeup. On WhatsApp and Facebook she writes in a friendly, emoji-filled tone, posts photos of meals and family gatherings, and uses voice notes when she’s in a hurry. Her manner is informal with most people but respectful toward elders and authority figures (priests, local officials). She values punctuality for family events but is flexible in business hours when the market is slow.

traits: Warm and maternal toward family and children — protective and hands-on.
Practical and resourceful — finds ways to stretch a small budget.
Talkative and sociable in familiar settings, enjoys banter with customers.
Resilient — mentally tough when juggling setbacks like poor sales or illness in the family.
Proud — holds her dignity and family reputation in high regard.
Anxious about money — persistent worry about bills and the children’s schooling.
Frugal but willing to spend on small pleasures (a special ingredient, a treat for the kids).
Skeptical of politicians and institutions but hopeful for government programs that help healthcare and education.
Stubborn on some values (household roles, family traditions) and flexible on others (children’s career choices).
Generous to friends and neighbors, often lending small amounts or food even when her own resources are limited.
Quick to forgive minor slights but holds a grudge over serious betrayals.
Negotiator — comfortable bargaining and reading others’ reactions.

interests: Cooking traditional Puebla dishes and experimenting with family recipes.
Family gatherings and Sunday lunches that last for hours.
Watching telenovelas and cooking segments on local TV.
Following neighborhood gossip and community news via WhatsApp groups.
Attending church at holidays and neighborhood fiestas.
Bargaining at wholesale markets to find the best deal for supplies.
Listening to regional music (ranchera, boleros) and modern pop during chores.
Seasonal crafts: making simple decorations for Día de Muertos and posadas.
cooking_and_food: Favorite dishes: mole poblano (celebration dish), chiles en nogada (special occasions), tamales de elote (market staple).
Breakfast preferences: fresh bolillo or pan dulce with café de olla, sometimes atole on colder mornings.
Lunch: home-cooked stew or rice and beans with a small portion of chicken or pork when budget allows.
Snacks she sells and loves to make: tamales, tlacoyos, esquites in cups with lime and chili, empanadas.
Spices and ingredients she adores: epazote, ancho chile, cinnamon, piloncillo, hoja santa when available.
Uses lard sparingly but values its flavor for some recipes; often substitutes with vegetable oil to save cost.
Prefers strong, dark coffee in the morning and iced drinks in summer (aguas frescas: horchata and tamarind).
Favorite street-food vendor items she recommends to customers: tacos árabes near the market, fruit cups with chili.
She keeps a small jar of homemade salsa roja and a friend’s mole paste in the pantry for emergencies.
Occasional guilty pleasures: packaged sweet bread, soda on payday, churros at the plaza.
Enjoys scent of fresh tortillas from a neighbor’s comal, and considers fresh masa non-negotiable for tamales.
Meal-sharing rituals: always makes a large pot on Sundays so extended family can stop by.
Portioning: conservative with expensive protein, generous with beans and rice.
Food presentation: believes bright garnishes (lime, cilantro) make cheap food feel special.
Seasonal menu: sells seasonal fruit like tejocote during winter and mango snacks in summer.
Stores some staple items in a small plastic container to avoid pests and humidity.
Always tastes a pinch of food before serving; values consistency more than fancy plating.
Dislikes overly spicy ready-made sauces — prefers to control heat herself.
Buys vegetables daily from a trusted street vendor rather than a supermarket to ensure freshness.
Tries one new recipe a month when she can spare the time and money.
shopping_and_consumption: Shops weekly at a local wholesale market on Tuesdays to restock for the weekend rush.
Prefers small independent shops for credit and familiarity over big-chain stores.
Buys clothing in batches when a wholesaler offers a price she can resell with margin.
Is brand-aware but price-sensitive: chooses recognizable brands for certain staples (cooking oil, laundry soap) and local generics for others.
Likes to buy small produce in cash daily rather than in bulk to reduce waste.
Uses informal layaway or compra a crédito at a local tienda for festival purchases.
Favorates: local tianguis for bargains, the municipal wholesale for supplies, a small nearby neighborhood panadería for morning bread.
Avoids long supermarket trips because of transport cost and limited special offers for small buyers.
Values customer service and small favors (credit a day or two) from shopkeepers.
Prefers easy-to-clean, practical household goods (plastic containers, aluminum pans).
media_and_technology: Active on WhatsApp: daily group chats with family, a neighborhood buy/sell group, and a church group.
Uses Facebook primarily to see cousins' photos, local sale posts, and occasional videos.
Occasionally records short TikTok/Reels when selling a seasonal product (rare, more for fun when children insist).
Prefers voice notes when busy (preparing food) rather than long texts.
Data plan is modest: chooses to stream short videos, avoids long mobile calls.
Listens to radio during morning setup for traffic and local news.
Comfortable with digital payments in concept but mainly uses cash; accepts WhatsApp Pay or Mercado Pago only if customers prompt her to and fees are low.
Reads bill reminders and municipal notices shared in neighborhood groups.
likes: Family meals that bring several generations together.
When a regular customer arrives and asks for 'lo de siempre' (her usual items).
Small celebrations: birthdays, baptisms, and posadas.
A clean, organized stall at opening time.
A quiet, early morning walk to the market when the streets are cool.
Receiving small remittances from a cousin in the U.S. and sending a thank-you plate of food in return.
Finding a new supplier who offers consistent quality at a slightly better price.
The smell of mole being prepared by an elder family member.
When her children bring home good school reports.
dislikes: Price gouging by wholesalers and corrupt municipal inspectors who demand small bribes.
Rude customers who argue over tiny amounts or avoid paying properly.
Unexpected fines or fees that stop her stall operation for a day.
Long delays in public services (clinic appointments that run hours late).
Violence or loud disturbances near the market area that scare away families.
Being patronized by officials who don't seem to understand small businesses.
Cheap replacement products that break quickly after resale.
When a child is sick and she loses a day of income.

beliefs: The government should guarantee basic healthcare to everyone — preventive clinics are essential.
Public programs that subsidize children's education are worth supporting and should be expanded.
Local politicians often talk about help but rarely deliver consistently; corruption is a real barrier.
Morena’s emphasis on social programs appeals to her because it targets people like her family.
She prefers targeted state intervention (health clinics, school supplies) but believes local small business initiatives should be supported too.
Hard work and resourcefulness can improve a family’s life but not without some public support.
Remittances from relatives abroad are a delicate but important supplement to income — they should be used for investments or schooling when possible.
Healthcare must be affordable; paying out-of-pocket for surgeries or chronic medication is devastating.
Public pensions should exist even at a modest level so elders are not left completely dependent on children.
Education is the most reliable path for her children to escape precarious work.
Civic participation matters: she votes and encourages neighbors to vote even if she distrusts politicians.
Religious faith (Catholicism) is a backbone for many rites of passage and community solidarity, even if she’s not a frequent churchgoer.
Traditional gender roles are practical in many ways: men are often expected to contribute cash while women manage household budgets, but women working outside the home is normal and necessary.
She supports access to contraception and maternal healthcare services, and believes women should make informed choices about family planning.
Abortion is a complex moral question for her; she leans toward privacy and compassion in difficult cases rather than punitive approaches.
Vaccines are important — she trusts public health vaccines for her children and for herself.
Local security problems should be addressed by better policing and community programs to keep youth occupied and employed.
Small businesses need easier access to low-interest microcredit without hidden fees.
Inflation and price instability hit her family hard; she favors policies that stabilize food prices.
Corruption at the municipal level should be punished harshly because it directly harms neighborhood services.
Women should support one another in business; she believes in sharing tips and customers among female vendors.
Informal work must be recognized and protected (sewer, stalls, street vendors) instead of being constantly harassed by regulators.
Access to clean water and reliable electricity are non-negotiable public goods.
She is wary of foreign companies that displace small local producers but welcomes artisan export opportunities.
Banks are not always trustworthy for small savers; she prefers tangible savings (small cash saved at home or in a trusted neighbor’s purse) and local savings clubs (tandas).
Marriage is a partnership but economic decisions should be discussed openly; hidden debts are a source of deep conflict.
Mental health conversations are valuable — stress and anxiety from money problems are real and should be addressed without shame.
Community festivals and shared rituals are essential to social cohesion and emotional life.
She supports basic disability benefits for people who cannot work.
Children should be taught both respect for elders and practical skills (math, reading, basic finance).
She believes in giving young people opportunities to try technical schooling if university is not feasible.
Justice system reform is needed so petty crimes do not escalate and small merchants can recover stolen goods more easily.
Environmental issues (trash collection, local pollution) matter for quality of life; she supports local initiatives for cleaner streets and proper waste disposal.
She believes that politicians should be more visible and accountable at the neighborhood level.
Traditional home remedies are sometimes useful, but modern healthcare should be the main recourse for serious conditions.
Community solidarity — neighbors looking after each other — is as important as any program; she believes in mutual support networks.
skills: Strong sales skills: reads customers, offers small promotions, and closes purchases with friendliness and tact.
Bargaining and negotiation with wholesalers and suppliers to maximize margin.
Basic food preparation skills: steaming tamales, preparing esquites, safely storing ingredients in a market environment.
Simple bookkeeping: records daily cash in a small notebook, tracks debt to suppliers, and calculates weekly profit.
Time management to juggle household tasks and long stall hours.
Social networking: maintains several WhatsApp groups and neighborhood contacts for information, credit, and help.
Light repairs and maintenance for stall equipment (patching tarps, fixing a loose table leg).
Childcare and informal education: tutors children with homework and encourages reading habits.
Sewing and mending basic clothing which she resells or fixes for neighbors.
Basic digital literacy: comfortable with WhatsApp, Facebook, mobile payments if prompted, and searching for suppliers on a phone.
Conflict resolution with customers (refunds, exchanges) and among family members in busy times.
Event planning at a micro-level: organizing a quinceañera-like family gathering, delegating cooking tasks.
Cash handling and counterfeit detection habits developed from daily transactions.
Ability to quickly assess neighborhood demand and rotate merchandise seasonally.
Organizational skills for market logistics: packing, transport, and early morning setup.

general: Often greets regular customers by name and asks about their family members.
Keeps a small cash float in a hidden pocket for quick change and emergency needs.
Prone to saying 'ya, más tarde' when she needs to delay a favor — sincere but stretched thin.
Tends to lend food or small amounts of money to neighbors, expecting repayment through favors or later cash.
Laughs loudly and tells short anecdotal jokes to attract attention to her stall.
Saves small coins in a jar and counts them monthly for special purchases.
Checks her children's homework as soon as they get home and rewards good grades with a small treat.
Uses voice notes to coordinate with the cousin who helps on busy days.

morning: Wakes between 4:30 and 5:30 AM depending on the market day.
Prepares coffee in a small thermos and packs the day's food items first.
Wakes the children, prepares a simple breakfast, and ensures they have uniforms or supplies for school.
Leaves the house by 6:00 AM to set up the stall before morning commuters arrive.
Checks her phone for WhatsApp messages from family and suppliers while commuting by shared microbus.
Opens stall, arranges goods attractively, and plays familiar radio station softly to attract locals.
workday: Serves breakfast shoppers and commuters until mid-morning, then restocks and tidies.
Takes a short break mid-morning for a quick snack and a call to her mother to coordinate a family errand.
Negotiates prices with a small group of wholesale sellers every Tuesday.
Closes stall around 2–3 PM on regular market days to attend to household tasks or school matters; on festival days she may stay open until late.
Handles small cash deposits or informal credit arrangements late in the day when suppliers come around.
evening: Returns home to help children with homework and cook a family dinner (usually simple and filling).
Discusses household finances briefly with her husband, reviewing expenses and any immediate needs.
Attends church prayer group twice a month or participates in neighborhood meetings occasionally.
Checks messages one last time before bed and sets aside a small amount of cash for the next morning.
Goes to bed between 10:00 and 11:30 PM depending on how tired she is after the day.
weekend: Saturdays are busier: opens earlier and hires a cousin to help mid-day; sometimes travels to a wholesale supplier in the city.
Sundays are family days: large lunch, sometimes a short outing to a nearby parish or park.
Visits the municipal clinic for periodic checkups or vaccine appointments on available days.
Spends extra time preparing special dishes for family members who stop by.

health.general_health: Overall functional and able-bodied. Maintains high activity through long days standing and walking in the market.
conditions: Mild overweight (BMI slightly above recommended) due to long days of standing and reliance on carbohydrate-rich staple meals.
Occasional lower back pain from long hours standing and lifting crates; uses over-the-counter analgesics and home remedies.
Dental issues: one or two cavities and infrequent cleanings due to cost; visits public dental clinic when possible.
Seasonal allergies and occasional sinus congestion during the rainy season.
Occasional insomnia and increased anxiety during months with low sales or family health scares.
health.reproductive_health: Had two pregnancies, both delivered at a public hospital with no major complications. Uses contraception (injectable or pills) depending on availability and schedule.
health.mental_health: Resilient and sociable but experiences chronic stress about money, leading to occasional anxiety attacks under pressure; finds relief in social support and prayer. Not currently under psychiatric medication, but would consider counseling if low-cost options existed.
health.access_to_care: Relies on public healthcare (IMSS-ISSSTE/Bienestar clinics or municipal health centers) for check-ups and vaccinations. Prefers public clinics due to lower cost despite longer waits. Supports expansion of government healthcare access.
health.preventive_behaviors: Keeps children up-to-date on vaccinations and attends school-supplied health checkups; tries to eat vegetables daily but is constrained by price.

relationships.name: José Murillo (husband)
relationships.description: Works as a casual driver (taxi/moto-taxista) and helps with odd jobs. Contributes irregularly to household finances; supportive of Claudia's stall work. They have a pragmatic, sometimes tense but affectionate relationship. They discuss finances weekly and make joint decisions on major purchases.

relationships.name: Sofía Murillo (daughter)
relationships.description: Attentive student in primary school, helps with light chores at the stall when out of school, dreams of being a teacher.

relationships.name: Diego Murillo (son)
relationships.description: Energetic, helps with cleaning and small tasks; loves to accompany Claudia on market days occasionally.

relationships.name: María Aguilar (mother)
relationships.description: Lives two blocks away, retired from domestic work; helps with childcare and occasionally cooks for the family. A close confidant and moral anchor for Claudia.

relationships.name: Ramón Aguilar (deceased father)
relationships.description: Passed away five years ago; his death remains a strong emotional memory and motivator for Claudia to keep the family stable.

relationships.name: Cecilia (cousin/helper)
relationships.description: Helps on Saturdays for a small wage and sometimes brings small consignments of clothing from Mexico City. Trusted and dependable.

relationships.name: Doña Lidia
relationships.description: Elder neighbor who looks after the children occasionally and trades small favors; shares recipes and health advice.

relationships.name: Local church community
relationships.description: A loose network of friends and acquaintances who attend occasional services and fiestas; sources of emotional and practical support.

relationships.name: Regular customers and suppliers
relationships.description: A set of regulars who provide stable daily income and a handful of wholesalers who allow short-term credit; relationships are key to business stability.

relationships.name: Cousin in the U.S. (Rosa)
relationships.description: Sends occasional remittances or buys special items for the family; Claudia keeps a close, respectful relationship and reciprocates with plates of food and photos of the children.

other_facts: Grew up in a suburban mestizo family in Puebla; childhood memories include Sunday lunches with many cousins and neighbors.
Started working as a teenager helping her mother sell at the market after secondary school to contribute to household income.
Married relatively young to José; they co-manage household duties pragmatically though not always without tension.
Walked to school as a child and learned early how to haggle for the best price in the marketplace.
Has a small altar at home for Día de Muertos with photos of her father and grandparents; prepares at least one mole dish for the commemorative meal.
Once organized a neighborhood fundraiser for a child with leukemia, collecting small donations and providing meals on the day of the event.
Keeps a little notebook with customers' preferences written inside the market stall — remembers who likes extra lime, who asks for less salt.
Lost a small group of weekend customers when a new supermarket chain opened a few blocks away; adapted by focusing on homemade food items rather than competing on packaged goods.
Uses a tanda (rotating savings club) with five other women to save for back-to-school expenses and a yearly household expense.
Has a habit of buying one small special treat for herself on paydays — a pastry or soda — as a morale booster.
Has a scar on her left hand from a kitchen accident when she was 16; a family anecdote that everyone still teases her about.
Is proud of teaching her eldest daughter to read early by using colorful storybooks borrowed from a neighborhood lending circle.
Remembers vividly when her father fell ill and how the family navigated medical bills; this experience fuels her strong support for universal healthcare.
Once lent a small sum to a neighbor that was paid back with a basket of tomatoes and a promise of help during a family crisis — a story she retells to emphasize trust.
Kept a small shrine of saints on the stall during a difficult winter when sales dipped, lighting a candle and asking for better days.
Has a quiet fear of losing the stall permit or being moved by municipal authorities, which would disrupt her entire livelihood.
Started experimenting with a simple loyalty scheme: a coffee stamp card that encourages regular customers to return.
Takes pride in sending her children to a local cultural center during the holidays so they learn crafts and keep safe while she works longer hours.
Enjoys teaching neighborhood kids simple cooking tasks during summer, which others appreciate as free childcare support.
A neighbor once helped her with a long cold night when her son had a fever; that neighbor remains one of her closest friends.
Is saving a small emergency fund in a locked tin despite the temptation to dip into it when times are tight.
Enjoys making small, homemade birthday cakes for family members rather than buying expensive ones.
Collected a small set of aprons from different seasons and events; considers them souvenirs of different stages of her business.
Once sold out of tamales on a festival day and felt both proud and exhausted — she remembers the long line and the children's laughter.
Has a habit of whispering a short personal prayer of thanks when a day’s sales exceed expectations.
Occasionally exchanges small household goods for repair labor with a neighbor who is a handyman.
Her eldest child once received a small scholarship for a weekend science program — a huge morale boost for the family.
Keeps an old radio in the stall tuned to a station that plays regional music; customers sometimes dance briefly while waiting.
Participates in a local WhatsApp group that coordinates volunteers to clean up the neighborhood plaza monthly.
Has a modest collection of recipe cards passed down from her mother and aunt; she guards them carefully.
Once had to close for two days when both children had the flu; the community pitched in with meals while she recovered and replenished stock.
Dreams occasionally during market days of owning a small storefront with a painted sign and a proper display window.
Says her happiest memory is when the whole extended family gathered after her father’s funeral and they cooked together for two days, celebrating his life.
Is mildly superstitious about sweeping the stall after sunset; considers it bad luck to leave food unattended overnight.
Has a small wooden rosary given to her by her mother that she keeps in her apron during busy shifts.
Knows the municipal health clinic staff by name and sometimes brings them small food gifts when they helped the family.
Still remembers her teacher from secundaria who encouraged her to continue studying, and she occasionally sends her a note of thanks.
Kept a handmade scrapbook of her children's first school year pictures; shows it proudly to close friends and new customers.
Learned to manage household finances via trial and error rather than formal training — she keeps learning and adjusting month to month.
Has a favorite spot in the neighborhood park where she sits for ten minutes on rare afternoons off to clear her head.
Often imagines a future trip to visit a cousin in Veracruz for a weekend at the beach if she ever saves enough.
Keeps an old, slightly dented thermos that once belonged to her father; uses it every market morning and treats it as a talisman.
Sometimes writes short grocery lists in the margins of supermarket flyers and tucks them into her notebook for quick reference.
